occurrences.line_text: O heauie record of the good Redcrosse,
Of treble good: good growes of euils priefe.
Of treble good: good growes of euils priefe.
But th'onely good, that growes of passed feare,
Whose secret filth good manners biddeth not be told.
As this good Prince redeemd the Redcrosse knight from bands.
Least so great good, as he for her had wrought,
Most enuious man, that grieues at neighbours good,
And though good lucke prolonged hath thy date,
But all the good is Gods, both power and eke will.
And all the day in doing good and godly deedes.
And knew his good to all of each degree,
And this good knight his way with me addrest,
And you good Sir, I wote that of your toyle,
Then Vna her besought, to be so good,
Gan him instruct in euery good behest,
During which time, in euery good behest
That word shall I (said he) auouchen good,
Great thankes and goodly meed to that good syre,
Full of great vertues, and for med'cine good.
Saue in that soile, where all good things did grow,
Both good and ill: O mornefull memory:
The good Sir Guyon gratiously to heare,
For to all good he enimy was still.
And knighthood tooke of good Sir Huons hand,
The which good fortune doth to you present.
A right good knight, and true of word ywis:
Or make you good amendment for the same:
For all he did, was to deceiue good knights,
So God ye speed, and send you good successe;
With right hands plighted, pledges of good will.
Whom when the good Sir Guyon did behold,
Gay steed with spurs did pricke, the good Sir Mortdant was.
That seeing good Sir Guyon, could vneath
To good and bad, the common Inne of rest;
Or by good prayers, or by other hap,
Yet not so good of deedes, as great of name,
Ill by ensample good doth often gayne.
Sith his good steed is lately from him gone;
And giue you eke good helpe to their decay,
All good and honour might therein be red:
He either enuying my toward good,
And staynd their prayses with thy least good part;
Honour, estate, and all this worldes good,
Here is the fountaine of the worldes good:
There the good Guyon he found slumbring fast
Ne all good knights, that shake well speare and shield:
Good or bad (gan his brother fierce reply)
And of that shield, more worthy of good knight;
His owne good sword Morddure, to cleaue his head.
Of my good sword and shield? The Palmer glad,
Good turnes be counted, as a seruile bond,
Fly fly, good knights, (said he) fly fast away
And many good knights slaine, that haue vs sought to saue.
But in good order, and with dew regard;
Not good nor seruiceable else for ought,
Not he, whom Greece, the Nourse of all good arts,
His life, and long good fortune vnto finall fate.
And endlesse moniments of his great good:
Good Claudius, that next was Emperour,
Then Coyll, and after him good Lucius,
This good king shortly without issew dide,
Not with so good successe, as she deseru'd;
Who whiles good fortune fauoured her might,
That gaue vnto vs all, what euer good we haue.
So fast as his good Courser could him beare,
His owne good sword Morddure, that neuer fayld
But his good Squire him helping vp with speed,
And of our safetie good heede to take;
Did wisely make, and good Agdistes call:
The foe of life, that good enuyes to all,
Which seeing good Sir Guyon, deare besought
By such good meanes he him discounselled,
'Mongst thousands good one wanton Dame to find:
Scorne the faire offer of good will profest;
And eke the Redcrosse knight gaue her good aid,
So was their fortune good, though wicked were their mind.
But wicked fortune mine, though mind be good,
Whom thy good fortune, hauing fate obayd,
Yet ought mens good endeuours them confirme,
Against the good king Oswald, who indewd
Ne shall the good Cadwallader with paine,
Ye see that good king Vther now doth make
Her to restraine, and giue her good reliefe,
They pourd in soueraine balme, and Nectar good,
Good both for earthly med'cine, and for heauenly food.
Which way she fared hath, good Sir tell out of hand.
Or all the good that euer yet I gat:
By your good counsell, or bold hardiment,
Do one, or other good, I you most humbly pray.
Of all good Ladies through the world so wide,
The want of his good Squire late left behind,
Of your gay sonne, that giues ye so good ayd
A laesie loord, for nothing good to donne,
It was to weete the good Sir Satyrane,
By this the good Sir Satyrane gan wake
Gainst natures law, and good behauioure:
Three hundred pledges for my good desartes,
And thrise three hundred thanks for my good partes
But thou good man, sith farre in sea we bee,
But he, that neuer good nor maners knew,
And but God turne the same to good soothsay,
Offend the good: for good by paragone
Offend the good: for good by paragone
But fast good will with gentle curtesyes,
The good man selfe, which then the Porter playd,
Escaped hardly, hardly praisd his wedlock good.
Good Sir, let not my rudenesse be no breach
What Ladie, man? (said Trompart) take good hart,
Which all good knights, that armes do beare this day,
And euery one as commune good her handeled.
For litle good of him is to be got,
Ne euer looked backe for good or ill,
Or hast thou, Lord, of good mens cause no heed?
What booteth then the good and righteous deed,
If good find grace, and righteousnesse reward,
Yet if that heauenly grace some good reliefe
Yet saw her not nor signe of her good speed,
For vnder maske of beautie and good grace,
To hurt good knights, was as it were her baude,
Good lucke presents you with yond louely mayd,
And made good semblance to his companie,
Ye will me now with like good turne repay,
And foule aduantage this good Knight dismayd,
As old and crooked and not good for ought.
Since so good fortune doth to you present
But wicked Time that all good thoughts doth waste,
Combing her golden lockes, as seemd her good:
Haue by good fortune found some beasts fresh spoyle,
Yet they were all with so good wariment
T'obey their riders hest, as seemed good.
Without regard of good, dyes like ill grounded seeds.
To Britomart was giuen by good right;
Vnto the vulgar for good gold insted,
Full glad of so good end, to them drew nere,
An happie life with grace and good accord,
Or what good fortune did to him afford,
And steale away the crowne of their good name;
To all, that on him lookt without good heed,
To my friends good, more then for mine owne sake,
He with good thewes and speaches well applyde,
Then good sir Claribell him thus bespake,
And by good fortune shortly him vnseated.
The Gate of good desert, whose goodly pride
As euery one had cause of good or ill.
All which that day in order seemly good
When good was onely for it selfe desyred,
That both to good and bad he dealeth right,
Nor tooke away his loue, but his owne proper good.
The spoile of peoples euill gotten good,
Were it not good that wrong were then surceast,
For well they hoped to haue got great good,
His owne good steed, which he had stolne, to clame;
For oft their lewdnes blotteth good deserts with blame.
Now with faire words; but words did little good,
Did her espy, and through my good endeuour
The portion of that good, which Fortune gaue her,
This doe I say, that what so good or ill
Yet my good lucke he shall not likewise pray;
Known by good markes, and perfect good espiall,
Known by good markes, and perfect good espiall,
By what good right doe you withhold this day?
Your right is good (sayd he) and so I deeme,
Your right is good (sayd he) and so I deeme,
That for such good him recompence with ill?
Did with sure promise of her good indeuour,
Fortune enuying good, hath felly frowned,
That will not take the offer of good hope,
Which if I might by your good office get,
Gan to demaund of her some tydings good,
Who will not stoupe with good, shall be made stoupe with harme.
He wold by all good means he might, deserue such grace.
And tell what euer it be, good or bad,
Nor good nor bad, ne euer lookt aside,
To lodge with him that night, vnles good cause empeach.
Was glad to yeeld vnto his good request:
And armes had borne, but little good could finde,
But by Gods grace, and her good heedinesse,
It as a token of good fortune tooke.
Vppon their wall good watch and ward did keepe.
And her good Knights, of which so braue a band
But thankt be God, and your good hardiment,
That his good steed, all were he much renound
To doe, what euer he thought good or fit.
Good hart in euils doth the euils much amend.
The which good Fortune to him offred faire.
To greet him the good fortune of his hand:
Haile good Sir Sergis, truest Knight aliue,
Or with her owne good will, I cannot read aright.
Your owne good shield in daungerous dismay?
By a good knight, the knight of the Redcrosse;
Fie on the pelfe, for which good name is sold,
A ship all readie (as good fortune fell)
And if she hapt of any good to heare,
For what so Enuie good or bad did fynd,
That all she sought, was mens good name to haue bereaued.
For what soeuer good by any sayd,
To hearke what any one did good report,
To throw amongst the good, which others had disprad.
Now tell, if please you, of the good successe,
Or good direction, how to enter in,
In which although good Fortune me befall,
Good Knights and Ladies true, and many else destroyd.
Nor land nor fee, for hyre of his good deede,
Their good, that none them rightly may reproue
Yet praise likewise deserue good thewes, enforst with paine.
In which he had good right gaynst all, that it gainesayd.
He burst into these words, as to him seemed good.
Of good king Meliogras which did rayne
Therefore, good Sir, sith now occasion fit
And turne we backe to good Sir Calidore;
T rue is, that whilome that good Poet sayd,
So well and wisely did that good old Knight
Of her good fame, and further gan deuize,
But Calidore with all good courtesie
When Calidore in seemly good array
For first, next after life, he tendered her good.
And by good fortune the plaine champion wonne:
The good Sir Bruin, growing farre in yeares;
Lo how good fortune doth to you present
Ne euer saw faire guize, ne learned good,
The good Sir Calepine, that farre was strayd,
And otherwhile with good encouragement,
That could his good to all, and well did weene,
In that good Hermits charge, whom he did pray
Gainst all, both good and bad, both most and least,
But sith we need good counsell (sayd the swaine)
Aread good sire, some counsell, that may vs sustaine.
Of that good Hermite both they tooke their leaue,
For well she knew the wayes to win good will
And how to please the minds of good and ill,
And her good dayes in dolorous disgrace:
And gaue his foe good hope of victory.
Yet no lesse thankes to you for your good will.
The good Sir Calepine, her owne true Knight,
For ioy of such good hap by heauenly grace.
But day, that doth discouer bad and good,
Then came to them a good old aged syre,
But Meliboee (so hight that good old man)
Gan greatly thanke his host and his good wife;
It is the mynd, that maketh good or ill,
Giue leaue awhyle, good father, in this shore
But the good man, nought tempted with the offer
From malicing, or grudging his good houre,
Good will and fauour. So it surely wrought
That good should from vs goe, then come in greater store.
Then forth the good old Meliboe was brought,
Old Meliboe and his good wife withall
Whereof was Lord the good Sir Bellamoure;
In perfect forme, as this good Lady felt,
A full good pecke within the vtmost brim,
Of good and bad alike, of low and hie;
The good Sir Pelleas him tooke in hand,
Was nigh beguiled with so goodly sight:
A goodly Lady clad in scarlot red,
Where grew two goodly trees, that faire did spred
With goodly purposes there as they sit:
A goodly building, brauely garnished,
And goodly galleries farre ouer laid,
It was a goodly heape for to behould,
So goodly brought them to the lowest staire
Goodly they all that knight do entertaine,
So forth they marchen in this goodly sort,
Greeting him goodly with new victorie,
Which she accepts, with thankes, and goodly gree,
His goodly corps on ragged cliffs yrent,
Thenceforth he kept her goodly company,
Yet goodly court he made still to his Dame,
To gayne so goodly guerdon, as she spake:
A goodly knight, faire marching by the way
A goodly person, and could menage faire
His goodly reason, and well guided speach
And calmd his wrath with goodly temperance.
O Goodly golden chaine, wherewith yfere
The verdant gras my couch did goodly dight,
Most goodly glee and louely blandishment
Gaue goodly gifts, the signes of gratefull mynd,
In goodly thewes, and godly exercise:
Each goodly thing is hardest to begin,
Him goodly greeted in her modest guise,
Loe two most goodly virgins came in place,
And goodly gan discourse of many a noble gest.
Into a goodly lodge, and gan despoile
That wonder was to heare her goodly speach:
With goodly counsell and aduisement right;
With goodly grace and comely personage,
Which to a goodly Citie led his vew;
Great thankes and goodly meed to that good syre,
That erst him goodly arm'd, now most of all him harm'd.
There grew a goodly tree him faire beside,
Whom farre before did march a goodly band
Did seeme such, as she was, a goodly maiden Queene.
Him goodly greetes, and faire does entertaine,
What needs me tell their feast and goodly guize,
Then stepped forth the goodly royall Mayd,
In whom great rule of Temp'raunce goodly doth appeare.
A goodly knight, all armd in harnesse meete,
Goodly comportance each to other beare,
For sith I know your goodly gouernaunce,
Through goodly handling and wise temperance.
Wherewith aboue all knights ye goodly seeme aguizd.
That all her goodly garments staind around,
Seemd to haue beene a goodly personage,
And goodly counsell, that for wounded hart
With goodly reason, and thus faire bespake;
And goodly gorgeous barbes, him found not theare.
In goodly garments, that her well became,
She led him vp into a goodly bowre,
With goodly meanes to pacifie, well as he can.
With sober grace, and goodly carriage:
On goodly courser thundring with his feet,
A goodly Ladie clad in hunters weed,
Through goodly mixture of complexions dew;
So when her goodly visage he beheld,
In faire defence and goodly menaging
For it the goodly peace of stayed mindes
Gaynd in Nemea goodly victoree;
And Guyon in them all shewes goodly maisteries.
Holding in hand a goodly arming sword,
Him Mammon answered; That goodly one,
Into a gardin goodly garnished
With a thicke Arber goodly ouer dight,
Next thereunto did grow a goodly tree,
That goodly was their glory to behold,
Here also sprong that goodly golden fruit,
So goodly did beguile the Guyler of the pray.
And with his goodly sisters, Graces three;
And goodly salued them; who nought againe
So goodly purpose they together fond,
To weet why on your shield so goodly scord
Whenas they spide a goodly castle, plast
She forth issewed with a goodly traine
Yet full of grace and goodly modestee,
Goodly she entertaind those noble knights,
So goodly workemanship should not endure:
All which compacted made a goodly Diapase.
There added was by goodly ordinaunce,
Which goodly order, and great workmans skill
And soone into a goodly Parlour brought,
Thus they awhile with court and goodly game,
Two goodly Beacons, set in watches stead,
His goodly reason, and graue personage,
Which for this Realme found many goodly layes,
And goodly well long time it gouerned,
Who in all godly thewes, and goodly prayse
A goodly creature, whom he deemd in mind
All happy peace and goodly gouernment
Attempred goodly well for health and for delight.
That goodly frame from ruine to sustaine:
Now gins this goodly frame of Temperance
They passing by, a goodly Ship did see,
Goodly it was enclosed round about,
His goodly conquest of the golden fleece,
All this, and more might in that goodly gate
Mantled with greene, and goodly beautifide
No gate, but like one, being goodly dight
It was her guise, all Straungers goodly so to greet.
Most goodly it with curious imageree
Some goodly swayne of honorable place,
Ne ought their goodly workmanship might saue
And on his arme addresse his goodly shield
Through goodly temperance, and affection chaste,
So goodly all agreed, they forth yfere did ryde.
O goodly vsage of those antique times,
A goodly Ladie did foreby them rush,
Most goodly meede, the fairest Dame aliue:
That Castle was most goodly edifyde,
Long were it to describe the goodly frame,
So was that chamber clad in goodly wize,
Their goodly entertainement and great glee:
And so did let her goodly visage to appere.
And goodly taught to tilt and turnament;
All were faire knights, and goodly well beseene,
Her hart on knight so goodly glorifide,
My glorious Soueraines goodly auncestrie,
If ay more goodly creature thou didst see;
And Howell Dha shall goodly well indew
The warlike minds, to learne her goodly lore,
A goodly Armour, and full rich aray,
All fretted round with gold, and goodly well beseene.
That all her goodly deeds do well declare.
Eftsoones her goodly shield addressing faire,
Whether more happie were, to win so goodly pray.
And cursed night, that reft from him so goodly scope.
But in braue sprite it kindles goodly fire,
The goodly ornaments of beautie bright;
The goodly Mayd full of diuinities,
Where when they saw that goodly boy, with blood
With this faire flowre your goodly girlonds dight,
Tempred with grace, and goodly modesty,
It were a goodly storie, to declare,
The house of goodly formes and faire aspects,
Goodly she gan faire Cytherea greet,
And welled goodly forth, that in short space
To be vpbrought in goodly womanhed,
In that same Gardin all the goodly flowres,
Does mow the flowring herbes and goodly things,
Their goodly meriment, and gay felicitie.
In all the lore of loue, and goodly womanhead.
Admyrd her goodly haueour, and found
That was to weet, the goodly Florimell;
Her goodly port, and to their senses vild,
It was a goodly Swaine, and of great might,
Shall be t'aduance thy goodly chastitee,
Or ought your goodly patience offend,
Her goodly personage and glorious hew,
Out of the goodly heauen amoued quight,
But to him louted low, and greeted goodly well.
Saw all this goodly sport, and grieued sore,
And all their goodly heards did gather round,
With goodly arras of great maiesty,
To search each secret of that goodly sted,
The goodly ordinance of this rich place,
Of Minstrals, making goodly meriment,
But painted plumes, in goodly order dight,
Goodly adorned, and exceeding faire:
And did suruay his goodly company:
And goodly well aduance, that goodly well was tryde.
And goodly well aduance, that goodly well was tryde.
Returning backe, those goodly roomes, which erst
Was to that goodly fellowship restor'd,
And made full goodly ioyance to her new found mate.
Now when this gallant with his goodly crew,
That had a goodly Ladie by his side,
With golden words, and goodly countenance,
How euer gay and goodly be the style,
To weete, two Ladies of most goodly hew,
But rul'd her thoughts with goodly gouernement,
She list discouer, and of goodly stature;
In braue aray and goodly amenance,
Thus when they all accorded goodly were,
Them seemd, that could so goodly riches gaine,
This goodly counterfesaunce he did frame.
And brought with her fro[m] thence that goodly belt away.
That goodly belt was Cestus hight by name,
To tell the feature of each goodly face.
He much more goodly glosse thereon doth shed,
Who was right glad to gaine so goodly meed:
To spoyle so goodly workmanship of nature,
So goodly graue, and full of princely aw,
Where goodly solace was vnto them made,
On him, whilst goodly grace she did him shew:
Which from that goodly glorious flowre proceed,
For though she were most faire, and goodly dyde,
Of him, who goodly learned had of yore
To whom the Prince thus goodly well replied;
It was a bridge ybuilt in goodly wize,
With golden letters goodly well enchaced,
The goodly workes, and stones of rich assay,
The Gate of good desert, whose goodly pride
Whose goodly workmanship farre past all other
I much admyring that so goodly frame,
And next to her sate goodly Shamefastnesse,
And darted forth delights, the which her goodly graced.
And in the midst of them a goodly mayd,
For goodly triumph and great iollyment,
The eares and hearts of all that goodly crew,
The noble Thamis, with all his goodly traine,
Cambridge or Oxford, Englands goodly beames.
The third, the goodly Barow, which doth hoord
Her goodly lockes adowne her backe did flow
All goodly damzels, deckt with long greene haire,
Ioyous Thalia, goodly Amphitrite,
In goodly wise, whereof it tooke his name,
Hauing great Lordships got and goodly farmes,
She ment him to corrupt with goodly meede;
Withouten pitty of her goodly hew,
In goodly measure, by their Makers might,
And spoyling all her geares and goodly ray,
The goodly seruice, the deuicefull sights,
And goodly gan to greet his braue emprise,
Ne of that goodly hew remayned ought,
Her goodly bow, which paints the liquid ayre;
So did this Ladies goodly forme decay,
With whom great feast and goodly glee he fond,
With whom a goodly doure I should haue got,
Both goodly portions, but of both the better she.
A goodly citty and a mighty one,
Who, as he could, them goodly well did greete,
A miracle of natures goodly grace,
Both goodly meede of him it purchase may,
To fight with him, and goodly die her last:
For he their host them goodly well did cheare,
There she receiued was in goodly wize
Whose goodly building when she did behould,
In glistering armes right goodly well beseene,
That goodly seem'd t'adorne her royall state,
Sate goodly Temperance in garments clene,
Of that great Ladie, who with goodly chere
Euen seuenteene goodly sonnes; which who had seene
Both goodly Castle, and both goodly Towne,
Both goodly Castle, and both goodly Towne,
Who with right humble thankes him goodly greeting,
And yeeld great thankes for their so goodly deed,
Whose goodly light then Phebus lampe doth shine more cleare?
And goodly fury into them infuse;
The goodly praise of Princely curtesie,
Right so from you all goodly vertues well
Which of all goodly manners is the ground,
Which haue so goodly, as ye can deuize,
